<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 645, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the principle of moments. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 122]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 134, 831, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 274, 536, 293]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 306, 146, 324]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 920, 355]]<|/det|> Place the load \(\mathbf{P}\) on the metre rule at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Place the metre rule on the pivot at the \(45.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Place load \(\mathbf{Q}\) on the rule and adjust its position so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 367, 170, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 367, 845, 386]]<|/det|> Record, in Table 2.1, the distance a between the centre of load \(\mathbf{P}\) and the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 399, 171, 416]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 399, 892, 416]]<|/det|> Measure and record in the table the distance \(b\) from the centre of load \(\mathbf{Q}\) to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 429, 171, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 920, 478]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, placing the load \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(15.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(20.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(25.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keep the pivot at the \(45.0 \text{cm}\) mark each time. Record all the readings in the table. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 492, 539, 509]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 518, 621, 672]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 910, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light passing through a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 149, 823, 787]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 797, 532, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 828, 133, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 920, 861]]<|/det|>
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper. Draw the outline of the block ABCD.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 875, 133, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 873, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
Remove the block and draw a normal **NL** at the centre of side **AB**. Label the point **E** where the normal crosses **AB**. Label the point **M** where the normal crosses **CD**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
Draw a line \(\mathbf{FE}\) to the left of the normal, and at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 175, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 119, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) on the line \(\mathbf{FE}\), placing one pin close to \(\mathbf{E}\). Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 175, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 165, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
Replace the block and observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Remove the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 243, 920, 261]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 892, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of draughts (moving air) on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 420, 120]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 450, 151]]<|/det|>
electric fan with four speed settings

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 155, 316, 171]]<|/det|>
supply of hot water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 176, 266, 191]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 288, 212]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 216, 386, 233]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 237, 245, 252]]<|/det|>
stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 351, 273]]<|/det|>
clamp, boss and stand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 858, 320]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of draughts on the rate of cooling of hot water. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 218, 350]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 655, 381]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 569, 412]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 918, 459]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 722, 490]]<|/det|>
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 551, 520]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 873, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer-related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge International Examinations Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cie.org.uk after the live examination series.
